Reverse transcription-quantitative PCR (RT-qPCR)-based tests are widely used to diagnose
coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). As a result that these tests cannot be done in local clinics where
RT-qPCR testing capability is lacking, rapid antigen tests (RATs) for COVID-19 based on lateral ﬂow
immunoassays are used for rapid diagnosis. However, their sensitivity compared with each other
and with RT-qPCR and infectious virus isolation has not been examined. Here, we compared the
sensitivity among four RATs by using severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2)
isolates and several types of COVID-19 patient specimens and compared their sensitivity with that
of RT-qPCR and infectious virus isolation. Although the RATs read the samples containing large
/ / www.mdpi.com journal viruses

Keywords: rapid antigen test; diagnosis; COVID-19; SARS-CoV-2

RNA extraction and high-throughput RT-qPCR systems have been developed. Although such tests are
widely utilized in public health laboratories and large well-equipped hospitals, they are unavailable
in local clinics where patients who suspect they have COVID-19 often go ﬁrst. Therefore, specimens
result and increases the anxiety of the suspected COVID-19 patients. To improve this situation, rapid
antigen tests (RATs) for COVID-19, which does not require speciﬁc and expensive machinery, have
been approved for clinical use in Japan and other countries, and the sensitivity of these tests has been
compared with that of several kinds of RT-qPCR [
the detection of isolated viruses. We also evaluated their e

4. Discussion
SARS-CoV-2 and QuickNavi COVID19 Ag. For specimens such as saliva and swabs, Standard Q
These three kits detected viral antigens in more than half of the specimens whose Cq values of RT-qPCR
were less than approximately 25. Therefore, these RATs may be suitable for the detection of COVID-19
patients with a high likelihood of transmitting the virus to others.
This ﬁnding indicates that the current RATs are likely to miss some COVID-19 patients who are
virus to others. Further studies are required to address this point. In addition, the present study used
ﬀ bu
isolated gave negative results with all of the RATs tested here. Nonetheless, these RATs need to be
improved with respect to their sensitivity.
rates of these kits. Therefore, studies on false-positive rates should be performed in the future to
determine the speciﬁcity of these and other RATs.

7 of 8
Here we evaluated the sensitivity of four RATs available in Japan in August 2020. The overall
sensitivity of Standard Q COVID-19 Ag and Espline SARS-CoV-2 was better than that of ImmunoAce
COVID-19 Ag, Espline SARS-CoV-2, and ImmunoAce SARS-CoV-2 had similar detection sensitivities.
in individuals who are shedding a large amount of SARS-CoV-2; that is, they may be useful to identify
All four RATs failed to detect viral antigens in several specimens from which virus was isolated.
shedding infectious SARS-CoV-2. However, it is unclear to what extent such patients would transmit
swab specimens that were soaked in transport medium; if the specimens were directly soaked in lysis
er, the sensitivity of the RATs might be improved. The recommended samples for these RATS
are nasopharyngeal swabs not saliva, and some of the saliva samples from which SARS-CoV-2 was
In this study, we focused on the sensitivity of four RATs; we did not evaluate the false-positive

International Research Center for Infectious Diseases, Department of Special Pathogens, Institute of Medical
 

Reverse transcription-quantitative PCR (RT-qPCR)-based tests are widely used to diagnose
coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). As a result that these tests cannot be done in local clinics where
RT-qPCR testing capability is lacking, rapid antigen tests (RATs) for COVID-19 based on lateral ﬂow
immunoassays are used for rapid diagnosis. However, their sensitivity compared with each other
and with RT-qPCR and infectious virus isolation has not been examined. Here, we compared the
sensitivity among four RATs by using severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2)
isolates and several types of COVID-19 patient specimens and compared their sensitivity with that
of RT-qPCR and infectious virus isolation. Although the RATs read the samples containing large
/ / www.mdpi.com journal viruses

Viruses 12 2020 , , 1420
are shedding infectious SARS-CoV-2.
Keywords: rapid antigen test; diagnosis; COVID-19; SARS-CoV-2
1. Introduction

using nasopharyngeal (N) swabs, throat (T) swabs, or saliva [
RNA extraction and high-throughput RT-qPCR systems have been developed. Although such tests are
widely utilized in public health laboratories and large well-equipped hospitals, they are unavailable
in local clinics where patients who suspect they have COVID-19 often go ﬁrst. Therefore, specimens
result and increases the anxiety of the suspected COVID-19 patients. To improve this situation, rapid
antigen tests (RATs) for COVID-19, which does not require speciﬁc and expensive machinery, have
been approved for clinical use in Japan and other countries, and the sensitivity of these tests has been
compared with that of several kinds of RT-qPCR [
the detection of isolated viruses. We also evaluated their e

4. Discussion
SARS-CoV-2 and QuickNavi COVID19 Ag. For specimens such as saliva and swabs, Standard Q
These three kits detected viral antigens in more than half of the specimens whose Cq values of RT-qPCR
were less than approximately 25. Therefore, these RATs may be suitable for the detection of COVID-19
patients with a high likelihood of transmitting the virus to others.
This ﬁnding indicates that the current RATs are likely to miss some COVID-19 patients who are
virus to others. Further studies are required to address this point. In addition, the present study used
ﬀ bu
isolated gave negative results with all of the RATs tested here. Nonetheless, these RATs need to be
improved with respect to their sensitivity.
rates of these kits. Therefore, studies on false-positive rates should be performed in the future to
determine the speciﬁcity of these and other RATs.

7 of 8
Here we evaluated the sensitivity of four RATs available in Japan in August 2020. The overall
sensitivity of Standard Q COVID-19 Ag and Espline SARS-CoV-2 was better than that of ImmunoAce
COVID-19 Ag, Espline SARS-CoV-2, and ImmunoAce SARS-CoV-2 had similar detection sensitivities.
in individuals who are shedding a large amount of SARS-CoV-2; that is, they may be useful to identify
All four RATs failed to detect viral antigens in several specimens from which virus was isolated.
shedding infectious SARS-CoV-2. However, it is unclear to what extent such patients would transmit
swab specimens that were soaked in transport medium; if the specimens were directly soaked in lysis
er, the sensitivity of the RATs might be improved. The recommended samples for these RATS
are nasopharyngeal swabs not saliva, and some of the saliva samples from which SARS-CoV-2 was
In this study, we focused on the sensitivity of four RATs; we did not evaluate the false-positive
